stream_context.summary: Kaze programmed the boss fight for Course 15, a mutated 'pentapus' Yoshi. The stream focused on implementing the tentacle attacks, including animations, spline-based hitboxes, and creating visual effects like portals and light beams to serve as clear gameplay warnings for the player.

development_findings.summary: The boss for Course 15 is a five-tentacled 'pentapus' Yoshi, an idea born from questioning why only octopuses are common.
development_findings.quote: He's the boss for course 15... It's a pentapose. I was thinking, how come there's only octopuses? Why is there no septapose or hexapose or pentapose?

development_findings.summary: The boss fight involves destroying weak spots on the tentacles to make the boss vulnerable, then attacking a primary weak spot on its nose to deal damage, repeated in a cycle.
development_findings.quote: The loop is basically, Yoshi is like floating around... you jump on his tentacle, you destroy the ward and then Yoshi gets weak. And his head goes down... on his nose, there's more wards. So you're going up there and you punch the ward and that's dealing damage to him.

development_findings.summary: The game will feature nine boss fights in its main courses, an increase from the six found in the original Super Mario 64.
development_findings.quote: We have nine boss fights in the main courses. We have six boss fights in the original Mario 64.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is considering using a static recompilation tool to create native ports of the game, which would eliminate the need for emulators.
development_findings.quote: I might legitimately just use YSK static recompilation to properly import the game to like everything at once. So you wouldn't even need an emulator.

development_findings.summary: A community member named Akumoid collaborated with Kaze to create a new, advanced reflection shader for the game, which Kaze was very pleased with.
development_findings.quote: A person called Akumoid has been DMing with me. They wanted to learn about N64 shaders and they wanted to help me make a good shader for this. And together we came up with this one here.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is implementing cryptographic messages that the boss will communicate through text boxes, with the intention that they will be difficult for players to decipher.

To prevent a bug where the player could get stuck inside the tentacle model, Kaze made the tentacle retract immediately after hitting Mario, prioritizing a smooth player experience over animation realism.
development_findings.quote: I'm thinking we're just gonna make it so that if the tentacle hits Mario, then it instantly retracts... they don't know it's for their own benefit, because I don't want them to get stuck like that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze deliberately avoids discussing his political beliefs to maintain a broader appeal, citing the 'halo effect' as his rationale.
context_findings.quote: If no one knows what my political beliefs are, then people are more likely to assume my political beliefs overlap with theirs and they will like me for it. So I think it's better to just not talk about or not make any controversial political statements. This is what all politicians do, I'm just being honest about it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a philosophical preference for precise language, believing the world would be better if people had to define their terms to use them.
context_findings.quote: I had a dream one time that people were not able to say words unless they could describe exactly what they mean... I feel like if we lived in a world like that our lives would be so much better.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses frustration with the common greeting 'How are you doing?', finding it irritating despite its polite intention.
context_findings.quote: How are you doing? That's like, my least favorite question. Because it's like, people being polite, but it's also like, pissing me off, so I can't react impolitely.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a firm policy regarding unofficial ports of his work: he allows them as long as the creators do not ask him for support.
context_findings.quote: My general policy is if you can do it on yourself without my help, you can do with my hacks whatever you want but as soon as you start asking me for help I'm gonna be annoyed.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reveals he used to hide crude 3D models in unused parts of his old ROM hacks as an inside joke for other hackers to discover.
context_findings.quote: In some of my old ROM hacks is I would import the 3D model of a large cock into Castle Grounds. And not use Castle Grounds on my hack... as soon as you use a ROM hacking tool to open my hack, you would just see a large cock.

biobak.summary: Biobak is responsible for creating the final model and textures for the Course 15 boss, working from a placeholder concept model made by Kaze.
biobak.quote: The textures on the boss are not final, though. They're more like a symbolic representation of what I want this to look like, so that when Biobak remakes my model, he knows what I was going for.

biobak.summary: Biobak is in charge of the final visual polish for Course 14, which is functionally complete but awaiting his artistic work.
biobak.quote: Course 14 is done but a lot of the visuals are like left for Biobak to do so it doesn't look as pretty as it should be.

badub.summary: A viewer recognized Badub's music, prompting Kaze to joke about his growing fame, indicating his compositions are becoming well-known.
badub.quote: I guess Badub is royalty now. He's famous.

zeina.summary: Zeina is responsible for creating the outside area for Course 13 and has been working on it for an extended period.
zeina.quote: Course 13 is missing the outside area. Zeina wanted to work on that, she's been working on it for a long time now.

key_stories.title: Designing the Attack Warning Light
key_stories.summary: To solve the problem of off-screen attacks, Kaze designed and implemented a light beam effect. He prioritized gameplay clarity over visual realism, iterating on the effect until it provided a clear and reliable warning to the player, even if it looked imperfect.
key_stories.challenge: Players needed a clear warning for boss attacks originating from off-screen to have a fair chance to dodge them.
key_stories.process: Kaze decided to add a light effect to the portals. He created a model, but the initial version was too subtle. He then realized render distance was preventing it from being seen from behind. After fixing that, he refined the light's size and timing to ensure it was a highly visible and reliable warning for the player.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze implemented a bright, cone-shaped light effect that emanates from the portal before the attack. Despite looking 'a bit bad,' it effectively serves its gameplay purpose, which he deemed more important than realism.
key_stories.key_quote: So I will say the light doesn't make 100% physical sense. But we need this to exist to be able to tell what's going on.

key_stories.title: Critiquing Unofficial PC Ports
key_stories.summary: When confronted with fan ports of his work, Kaze balances appreciation for the effort with frank criticism of their technical flaws. He analyzed a port of 'Peach's Fury' live on stream, explaining his hands-off policy and expressing doubt that a complex project like RTYI could be successfully ported by the community.
key_stories.challenge: Fans frequently attempt to port Kaze's hacks to PC, but the results are often buggy and incomplete, creating a dilemma about how to respond.
key_stories.process: A viewer shared a video of a fan port. Kaze first saw an old, broken version and was critical. Upon seeing a more updated version, he gave a detailed critique, acknowledging improvements while still pointing out significant bugs and non-functional elements like the carousel.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze maintains his policy of allowing ports as long as he isn't asked for help. He remains skeptical that a complex game like RTYI can be ported accurately by fans due to its extensive custom code.
key_stories.key_quote: My general policy is if you can do it on yourself without my help, you can do with my hacks whatever you want but as soon as you start asking me for help I'm gonna be annoyed.
